Note.Content: Most English versions interpret הַבֹּשֶׁת "the shame" as a reference to Baal (explicitly REB CEV GNT | NJPS "the Shameful Thing") or idols (NIV "shameful gods"). Cf. also the commentaries of Rudolph, Holladay, Lundbom (but see Craigie/Kelly/Drinkard, following Seebass in TDOT II:55). See also JER 11:13, HOS 9:10 for interchange between Boshet and Baal (relatively common also in proper names).

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: = action by which someone consumes food; with or without explicit object
= action by which someone gives other people food for consumption, sometimes with the added connotation that these people are actually forced to consume it; with or without explicit object
= action by which people or objects are removed from existence in a violent way ◄ as food that is eaten
literally: to eat (goods); hence = pattern of actions by which someone makes a living off material goods until they are gone; ≈ often associated with joy
literally: to give (goods) to eat; hence = action by which someone enables someone else to make a living off material goods until they are gone; ≈ often associated with joy

Glosses.Gloss: to give to eat > to give to enjoy

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: literally: to eat space; hence: = state in which something takes up space that would normally belong to another object
literally: to eat (an offering); hence: = process by which a deity receives a burnt-offering; ≈ used of idols only
literally: to eat words; hence: = action by which someone listens carefully to someone else's words

Glosses.Gloss: to eat words > to listen carefully to (someone's) words

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: literally: to eat the fruits (of something); hence: = action by which someone accepts the consequences of an attitude or way of life ◄ as if they were the fruits of a tree; ≈ this expression can have both a positive or a negative sense

Glosses.Gloss: to eat the fruits > to bear the consequences
